meta_data.title: Question & Response Session // Why Does God Allow Church Leaders to Commit Suicide?

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner and I am joined by Chris Sherritt, Chris Legge, and Brent Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner and I'm here in the studio with Brent Starnes and Chris Legge. Hey guys. Hey. Good to see you. We're continuing our Q&A. We've had a couple of little breaks, right? Yes, we have. So we did a Q&A and then we had the... Is that when the ladies came in and had a conversation? Did you want to say anything specifically? There was one comment, which by the way, thanks guys. That was great. Yes, specifically Carly. That was specifically Carly. Kim and Mary Lee. Kim and Mary Lee. I think that's who it was. Getting their perspective, I don't know their ages. They're millennial slash Gen Z-ish. And so I know a lot of them have friends who have wrestled through this deconstruction. And I think probably even some of their questions inspired this podcast in some ways, like the fact that they were so concerned about friends who are wrestling. And so to be able to come at it from a different perspective, there was one thing that came up a few times that I wanted to comment on. It was the idea, and I remember who said at first, maybe Mary Lee, who threw out that there was a time in her life when she was, and I'm paraphrasing here, kind of surrounded by non-believers, surrounded by... And I think it was kind of a missional context, if I remember correctly. It was almost a charge. Yeah. And so then she said, the way she said was, and again, given her experience, this makes sense, everybody ought to try to find a time when they can be surrounded by non-believers like that for an extended period. And as I listened to it, I thought, okay, that's a good general advice for someone who's like Mary Lee, well-established, well-anchored, well-disciplined in her life. And I feel confident she's not here. At the time I wanted to ask, like in the room, I wanted to go, so what were your relationships with Christian friends and the church and discipleship like during that time? Right. And so I think the way we ought to think about that is, as human beings, we're so flawed, like sheep, the Bible says, we just wander off because we're kind of dumb that way. And so, like the old school, do you guys remember the... I don't know if you all ever did this, I'm so old, but the sitting around the campfire and having somebody take a coal out of the campfire and walk away and show how when it gets away from the fire, it cools off and it loses its light and it loses its heat. Okay, anyway. No, I mean, that's a cool word picture though. And so it was done every year at camp when I was going out again and again and again, like, yes, we get it. Anyway, it all hold hands. It only takes a spot. Yeah, there you go. So it's amazing how bad camp could be. But that picture was, there's still something accurate to you, like when Jesus sits with tax collectors and prostitutes and others, but he also is disciplined to spend time alone with the Father, to spend time with his family who are strong in their faith, to spend time with his friends. And so what I would add to that is if you're someone who is going to be on a missional relationship, whether it's in college, whether it's with groups of friends, whether it's whatever, that's not in competition with also sticking with your spiritual disciplines, with having good friends who are believers, with being involved in a local church and all that. And I suspect if I had been there and asked Mary Lee that question, she would have said, oh, that's, that's true. I did have this. It's just that, of course, we as Christians have no problems surrounding ourselves being surrounded by people who don't agree with us. In fact, that should be a fairly normal experience. It's hard when you work in a church, am I right? But we intentionally have friends who, one, it just enriches your life a little bit to be around people with different perspectives and to learn from them and to love people like that. Also, it's part of our calling to reach out to people. So don't hear me disagreeing with what Mary Lee said. I'm just adding a little, I don't know, color commentary to it. You made a courageous decision and apparently you made it long before this moment. Right. But, but exactly we want it to be black and white. Right. We don't have to be very simple and it isn't. Also with the mental illness issues, with the motivational issues, even just with the biblical issues. I don't think it's that easy, but what I will say is I do think a barring an extraordinary thing like a grenade or you being trapped on the top of the world trade center and the feet, your shoes are starting to melt. Suicide isn't necessary. Yeah. I mean, barring those super extreme examples, it's not necessary. And if you're out there and you're feeling that sense of hopelessness or despair, don't, don't let that stay. And don't feel stigmatized. You may be stigmatized in your family or in your circle, but you won't be here. We can at least help you find a community. Even if it's someplace else will help you find a community that would not stigmatize someone who feels suicidal. It's just such a normal part of my life as a therapist to talk to people who week to week to week feel suicidal. And I consider them super courageous that they push through and they fight it. And who knows what the spiritual significance of that is down the road. I mean, they're fighting some battle that most of us will never carry, at least not to the degree they do. And they're making a faithful decision week after week to trust God instead of what they want. Yeah, man, that's huge. So I'm proud to work with people who wrestle with that. So anyway, I mean, this, this question actually took a lot longer of a turn, but I'm really glad that we, that we were able to address it. Thank you for whoever asked. This was an anonymous one. And I'm sure we'll tackle some more. And I would say if this person's pastor committed suicide or their father or their friend or someone in the church, man, we are brokenhearted with you. We have experienced that in this church. And so just to recognize that's super hard and our heart goes out to you. And if you need someone to talk to, feel free to let us know. We'll find someone. Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

Exactly.
So, um, but the, you were saying, yeah, exactly.
And so a guy came up and said like, Hey, I noticed you taking more deep breaths than
normal in the sermon.
Like, is everything okay?
Like, wow.
What's weird is that week I actually could totally authentically say, no, I'm, I feel
like things are really good.
I don't, I don't feel any extra stress right now.
Now if he'd asked me this last Sunday, I just like, boy, you have lunch?
Cause I got a lot to tell you.
Um, but, but it's a, um, I just appreciated him coming and checking.
I mean, don't hesitate to check on your pastors and staff members.
Like it's somehow taboo.
People think they shouldn't check because it's like, Oh, you're the pastor.
You should be fine.
And it's just, it's like, it's, um, just continuing the problem of assuming that pastors don't
struggle with things that other people do.
And so by not checking on them, you're assuming like everything in your life must be fine
all the time.
And you don't need me, a layperson to check.
It's like, no, no, that's not it at all.
The opposite.
We, and it's a good, but I will, again, I can't speak for your pastor.
Maybe your pastor will be offended by that.
That doesn't mean now if they're offended by it, then they probably need it more, not
less, but it's just been fascinating.
We have so many former pastors who go to this church as well that I've had three or four
of them come to me and say, Hey, I've worked on church staff.
Have you ever need someone to talk to blah, blah, blah?
Like it's just fascinating that they know this is a need.
Um, but I think I mentioned, I mentioned getting the two over shepherds in our last podcast,
I think that realizing I went through a tough time and thought, Oh man, everyone who I could
go to right now kind of depends on me.
And if I go to them and go, Hey, I'm falling apart, that's gonna, I may have 70 points
of stress, but when they hear I'm falling apart, that's going to be 90 points of stress
for them because they're powerless to fix it.
And so realizing I needed a couple of people in my life who I could go to if I'm falling
apart, that it's not, it's not a stressor for them.
If I'm falling, like they're not dependent on me in any way.
And so, um, it was just healthy.
I have tons of friends and tons of people I could go to, but what if it was at the really
at the worst and realizing I probably need a couple of people I could go to and say,
yeah, I'm kind of hanging on by my fingernails here.
I don't, that doesn't feel like me.
Like I don't think I would ever get there, but maybe that's just pride.
And so I need to know that that's a possibility.
And also just to say that if a pastor does commit suicide, it doesn't mean that somehow
it's the fault of the people who didn't check on him.
That's a great point too.
That's right.
And, and too, I think it's helpful to note that in the sermons that, that you've preached
on suicide, a lot of the struggle that comes with, I mean, suicide is such a difficult
thing anyway, but especially if you're assuming that it is the unforgivable sin, which you
have addressed really well in the sermon.
It is not the case.
But if you think it's the unforgivable sin and then think that God allowed your pastor
to commit it, like that adds another layer of complication.
That's a really good point.
Yeah, definitely.
If you, if you're under the impression that suicide is somehow the unforgivable sin, then
please go listen to one of those, at least two, I know two sermons we've done on that,
because that is not, that is not biblically accurate.
And we, and in those sermons, you come at it from a very biblical perspective.
It's not just like, Hey, this is kind of what I think.
No, no, no, it's, it's like, I combine the, what I know as a psychologist with what I
know as a student of the Bible, but, but, but especially since it's a sermon, it is anchored
primarily in scriptural truth.
But it is, it's amazing how even just the question list, all the suicides in the Bible.
And it's amazing how many Christians can name one, they know Judas and they don't realize,
wait a minute, we honor Samson for suicide.
And so we always want to make things like mental illness issues or even suicide of black
and white clear issue.
And it just isn't like, I think in one of them I talk about.
So when a secret service agent steps in front of a bullet and gets shot, do you go, Oh,
he's so selfish.
Yeah.
Like, cause that's a lot of times what you'll hear when you're talking about suicide is,
Oh, they were just being selfishly.
Well, I mean, maybe humans are selfish.
That selfishness could be a motivation for suicide.
So can the ultimate self sacrifice.
A Marine who jumps on a grenade is you don't go, Oh, he's so selfish.
You're like, Oh, wow.
That's well, and to, to that point, I remember hearing a Marine talk about, and this guy
who was early in his career, but he had said like, Oh, well that's cowardice.
You're not willing to, if you know, somebody is committing suicide, it's because they're
a coward.
Right.
And so, but it's like, okay, but if you, but if you jumped on a grenade in front of your
friends, I wouldn't can, I wouldn't consider that person.
No, that's not a coward.
You made a courageous decision and apparently you made it long before this moment.
Right.
But, but exactly we want it to be black and white.
Right.
We don't have to be very simple and it isn't.
Also with the mental illness issues, with the motivational issues, even just with the
biblical issues.
I don't think it's that easy, but what I will say is I do think a barring an extraordinary
thing like a grenade or you being trapped on the top of the world trade center and the
feet, your shoes are starting to melt.
Suicide isn't necessary.
Yeah.
I mean, barring those super extreme examples, it's not necessary.
And if you're out there and you're feeling that sense of hopelessness or despair, don't,
don't let that stay.
And don't feel stigmatized.
You may be stigmatized in your family or in your circle, but you won't be here.
We can at least help you find a community.
Even if it's someplace else will help you find a community that would not stigmatize
someone who feels suicidal.
It's just such a normal part of my life as a therapist to talk to people who week to
week to week feel suicidal.
And I consider them super courageous that they push through and they fight it.
And who knows what the spiritual significance of that is down the road.
I mean, they're fighting some battle that most of us will never carry, at least not
to the degree they do.
And they're making a faithful decision week after week to trust God instead of what they
want.
Yeah, man, that's huge.
So I'm proud to work with people who wrestle with that.
So anyway, I mean, this, this question actually took a lot longer of a turn, but I'm really
glad that we, that we were able to address it.
Thank you for whoever asked.
This was an anonymous one.
And I'm sure we'll tackle some more.
And I would say if this person's pastor committed suicide or their father or their friend or
someone in the church, man, we are brokenhearted with you.
We have experienced that in this church.
And so just to recognize that's super hard and our heart goes out to you.
And if you need someone to talk to, feel free to let us know.
We'll find someone.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
We'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org.
Reconstructed faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up.
Trust God.
Search for answers.
